content:
After a few months of switching between my virtual notebook and my IDE, I stumbled upon a new, innovative solution; Jupyter Lab
Project Jupyter itself was born out of the IPython project, quickly gaining a reputation for 100% free and opensource high quality projects, one of which is Jupyter Lab Jupyter Lab, in the words of the Jupyter Project themselves, is a “Web-based flexible interactive development environment for Jupyter notebooks, code, and data with support for extensions.” It supports their custom IPYNB (IPython Notebook) file format, a sort of Markdown + python combination, plus other languages such as R, C++, Vanilla Python, and Julia.
Installation First, you want to have Anaconda Python installed (Skip if you have it installed.) Windows x64: https://repo.anaconda.com/archive/Anaconda3-2021.05-Windows-x86_64.exe MacOS x64: https://repo.anaconda.com/archive/Anaconda3-2021.05-MacOSX-x86_64.pkg Linux x64: https://repo.anaconda.com/archive/Anaconda3-2021.05-Linux-x86_64.sh Wait for the graphical installers to finish. Then in the Anaconda CMD Prompt (The app labeld Anaconda Prompt), execute the following command.  conda install -c conda-forge jupyterlab 
After the installation has finished, execute the following command in the same prompt
 jupyter notebook  That's it! You now have Jupyter Lab installed!
summary:
After a few months of switching between my virtual notebook and my IDE, I stumbled upon a new, innovative solution; Jupyter Lab
Project Jupyter itself was born out of the IPython project, quickly gaining a reputation for 100% free and opensource high quality projects, one of which is Jupyter Lab Jupyter Lab, in the words of the Jupyter Project themselves, is a “Web-based flexible interactive development environment for Jupyter notebooks, code, and data with support for extensions.
title: Jupyter Lab, a note taking IDE

content:
This guide NOT for beginners. You might need to read freeCodeCamp.org’s Docker for dummies
Step 1: Install Docker This will depend on platform/os but most people (e.g running some form of linux on an x64 cpu) should be able to run the code below. (Note you do need to )
 curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh   sh get-docker.sh  Step 2: Run hello-world on docker to see if Docker is functional Now that we have Docker installed, we need to see if its functional so that it can succsessfully run our minecraft server. Execute
 docker pull hello-world docker run hello-world  It should print hello world with some additional content. Then execute
 docker rm hello-world  Step 3: Run the Minecraft Server To run the minecraft server, execute
 docker pull itzg/minecraft-server docker run -d -v /path/on/host:/data \ -e TYPE=PAPER \ -p 25565:25565 -e EULA=TRUE --name mc itzg/minecraft-server  Your Minecraft server should be availible at the ip address of your Docker server
summary:
This guide NOT for beginners. You might need to read freeCodeCamp.org’s Docker for dummies
Step 1: Install Docker This will depend on platform/os but most people (e.g running some form of linux on an x64 cpu) should be able to run the code below. (Note you do need to )
 curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh   sh get-docker.sh  Step 2: Run hello-world on docker to see if Docker is functional Now that we have Docker installed, we need to see if its functional so that it can succsessfully run our minecraft server.
title: Minecraft Server on Docker guide

content: The site rewrite is complete! It went through many phases of being writting in various different languages. It first started of in ReactJS, then Angular, then ReactJS, and finally Hugo. Its been an absolute blast learning Javascript and Sass to make a professional-esque blog site. Thanks to Hugo and Github Pages for making anyone be able to make a free, high quality, secure, and open-source website.

Its been an absolute blast learning Javascript and Sass to make a professional-esque blog site. title: Site rewrite complete!

content: This is my first post. I’m currently going to use this blog for some Front-End dev things/Minecraft dev things. Its currently written in html/css but I’m planing to rewrite it using a static site generator (SSG) called Hugo. Once that’s complete I’ll probably start writing actual blog posts.
